channel.title: attack.defense_evasion on My New Hugo Site
channel.description: Recent content in attack.defense_evasion on My New Hugo Site

item.title: Explorer NOUACCHECK Flag
item.description: Detects suspicious starts of explorer.exe that use the /NOUACCHECK flag that allows to run all sub processes of that newly started explorer.exe without any UAC checks

item.title: Wlrmdr Lolbin Use as Laucher
item.description: Detects use of Wlrmdr.exe in which the -u parameter is passed to ShellExecute

item.title: Registry Defender Exclusions
item.description: Qbot used reg.exe to add Defender folder exceptions for folders within AppData and ProgramData.

item.title: Process Access via TrolleyExpress Exclusion
item.description: Detects a possible process memory dump that uses the white-listed Citrix TrolleyExpress.exe filename as a way to dump the lsass process memory

item.title: Suspicious Recursif Takeown
item.description: Adversaries can interact with the DACLs using built-in Windows commands takeown which can grant adversaries higher permissions on specific files and folders

item.title: Use IE Registry for Persistence
item.description: Use IE registry to hide a scripts

item.title: Blackbyte Ransomware Registry
item.description: BlackByte set three different registry values to escalate privileges and begin setting the stage for lateral movement and encryption

item.title: Suspicious Execution of InstallUtil Without Log
item.description: Uses the .NET InstallUtil.exe application in order to execute image without log

item.title: Disable System Firewall
item.description: Detects disabling of system firewalls which could be used by adversaries to bypass controls that limit usage of the network.

item.title: Suspicious Creation with Colorcpl
item.description: Once executed, colorcpl.exe will copy the arbitrary file to c:\windows\system32\spool\drivers\color\

item.title: Delete Log from Application
item.description: Deletion of log files is a known anti-forensic technique

item.title: Disable Administrative Share Creation at Startup
item.description: Administrative shares are hidden network shares created by Microsoftâ€™s Windows NT operating systems that grant system administrators remote access to every disk volume on a network-connected system

item.title: Dism Remove Online Package
item.description: Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool. DISM is used to enumerate, install, uninstall, configure, and update features and packages in Windows images

item.title: Msiexec Initiated Connection
item.description: Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

item.title: Suspicious Msiexec Execute Arbitrary DLL
item.description: Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

item.title: Suspicious Msiexec Quiet Install
item.description: Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

item.title: Obfuscated Command Line Using Special Unicode Characters
item.description: Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit.

item.title: Suspicious Start-Process PassThru
item.description: Powershell use PassThru option to start in background

item.title: Suspicious Unblock-File
item.description: Remove the Zone.Identifier alternate data stream which identifies the file as downloaded from the internet.

item.title: Use Remove-Item to Delete File
item.description: Powershell Remove-Item with -Path to delete a file or a folder with “-Recurse”

item.description: Detects suspicious command line patterns used when rundll32 is used to run JavaScript code

item.title: Sysmon Configuration Change
item.description: Detects a Sysmon configuration change, which could be the result of a legitimate reconfiguration or someone trying manipulate the configuration

item.title: Uninstall Sysinternals Sysmon
item.description: Detects the uninstallation of Sysinternals Sysmon, which could be the result of legitimate administration or a manipulation for defense evasion

item.title: Suspicious Regsvr32 HTTP IP Pattern
item.description: Detects a certain command line flag combination used by regsvr32 when used to download and register a DLL from a remote address which uses HTTP (not HTTPS) and a IP address and not FQDN

item.title: DevInit Lolbin Download
item.description: Detects a certain command line flag combination used by devinit.exe lolbin to download arbitrary MSI packages on a Windows system

item.title: NodejsTools PressAnyKey Lolbin
item.description: Detects a certain command line flag combination used by Microsoft.NodejsTools.PressAnyKey.exe that can be used to execute any other binary

item.title: Procdump Evasion
item.description: Detects uses of the SysInternals Procdump utility in which procdump or its output get renamed or a dump file is moved ot copied to a different name

item.title: Abuse of Service Permissions to Hide Services in Tools
item.description: Detection of sc.exe utility adding a new service with special permission which hides that service.

item.title: False Sysinternals Suite Tools
item.description: Rename as a legitim Sysinternals Suite tools to evade detection

item.title: Suspicious NT Resource Kit Auditpol Usage
item.description: Threat actors can use an older version of the auditpol binary available inside the NT resource kit to change audit policy configuration to impair detection capability. This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.

item.title: CleanWipe Usage
item.description: Detects the use of CleanWipe a tool usually used to delete Symantec antivirus.

item.description: Extract data from cab file and hide it in an alternate data stream

item.description: Detects extraction of files with usage of steghide binary, the adversaries may use this technique to prevent the detection of hidden information.

item.title: DNS-over-HTTPS Enabled by Registry
item.description: Detects when a user enables DNS-over-HTTPS. This can be used to hide internet activity or be used to hide the process of exfiltrating data. With this enabled organization will lose visibility into data such as query type, response and originating IP that are used to determine bad actors.

item.title: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS New Server
item.description: This detection uses AzureActivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the creation or update of a server instance in an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service. A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server instance to spoof AD FS signing logs. There is no need to compromise an on-prem AD FS server. This can be done programmatically via HTTP requests to Azure.

item.title: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS Service Delete
item.description: This detection uses AzureActivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the deletion of an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service instance in a tenant. A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server to spoof AD FS signing logs. The health AD FS service can then be deleted after it is not longer needed via HTTP requests to Azure.

item.description: Detects suspicious Splwow64.exe process without any command line parameters

item.title: EfsPotato Named Pipe
item.description: Detects the pattern of a pipe name as used by the tool EfsPotato

item.title: Powerup Write Hijack DLL
item.description: Powerup tool’s Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation. In it’s default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command. The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

item.title: Masquerading as Linux Crond Process
item.description: Masquerading occurs when the name or location of an executable, legitimate or malicious, is manipulated or abused for the sake of evading defenses and observation. Several different variations of this technique have been observed.

item.title: Suspicious Remote Thread Created
item.description: Offensive tradecraft is switching away from using APIs like “CreateRemoteThread”, however, this is still largely observed in the wild. This rule aims to detect suspicious processes (those we would not expect to behave in this way like word.exe or outlook.exe) creating remote threads on other processes. It is a generalistic rule, but it should have a low FP ratio due to the selected range of processes.

item.title: New or Renamed User Account with '$' in Attribute 'SamAccountName'.
item.description: Detects possible bypass EDR and SIEM via abnormal user account name.

item.title: Svchost DLL Search Order Hijack
item.description: IKEEXT and SessionEnv service, as they call LoadLibrary on files that do not exist within C:\Windows\System32\ by default. An attacker can place their malicious logic within the PROCESS_ATTACH block of their library and restart the aforementioned services “svchost.exe -k netsvcs” to gain code execution on a remote machine.

item.title: Disabling Windows Event Auditing
item.description: Detects scenarios where system auditing (ie: windows event log auditing) is disabled. This may be used in a scenario where an entity would want to bypass local logging to evade detection when windows event logging is enabled and reviewed. Also, it is recommended to turn off “Local Group Policy Object Processing” via GPO, which will make sure that Active Directory GPOs take precedence over local/edited computer policies via something such as “gpedit.msc”. Please note, that disabling “Local Group Policy Object Processing” may cause an issue in scenarios of one off specific GPO modifications – however it is recommended to perform these modifications in Active Directory anyways.

item.title: Ps.exe Renamed SysInternals Tool
item.description: Detects renamed SysInternals tool execution with a binary named ps.exe as used by Dragonfly APT group and documented in TA17-293A report

item.title: ZxShell Malware
item.description: Detects a ZxShell start by the called and well-known function name

item.title: Secure Deletion with SDelete
item.description: Detects renaming of file while deletion with SDelete tool.

item.title: DHCP Callout DLL Installation
item.description: Detects the installation of a Callout DLL via CalloutDlls and CalloutEnabled parameter in Registry, which can be used to execute code in context of the DHCP server (restart required)

item.description: This rule detects a DHCP server error in which a specified Callout DLL (in registry) could not be loaded

item.title: Account Tampering - Suspicious Failed Logon Reasons

item.title: Abusing Findstr for Defense Evasion
item.description: Attackers can use findstr to hide their artifacts or search specific strings and evade defense mechanism

item.title: Abusing Print Executable
item.description: Attackers can use print.exe for remote file copy

item.title: Abusing Windows Telemetry For Persistence
item.description: Windows telemetry makes use of the binary CompatTelRunner.exe to run a variety of commands and perform the actual telemetry collections. This binary was created to be easily extensible, and to that end, it relies on the registry to instruct on which commands to run. The problem is, it will run any arbitrary command without restriction of location or type.

item.title: Abusing Windows Telemetry For Persistence
item.description: Windows telemetry makes use of the binary CompatTelRunner.exe to run a variety of commands and perform the actual telemetry collections. This binary was created to be easily extensible, and to that end, it relies on the registry to instruct on which commands to run. The problem is, it will run any arbitrary command without restriction of location or type.

item.title: Detect Virtualbox Driver Installation OR Starting Of VMs
item.description: Adversaries can carry out malicious operations using a virtual instance to avoid detection. This rule is built to detect the registration of the Virtualbox driver or start of a Virtualbox VM.

item.title: Detecting Fake Instances Of Hxtsr.exe
item.description: HxTsr.exe is a Microsoft compressed executable file called Microsoft Outlook Communications.HxTsr.exe is part of Outlook apps, because it resides in a hidden “WindowsApps” subfolder of “C:\Program Files”. Its path includes a version number, e.g., “C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\microsoft.windowscommunicationsapps_17.7466.41167.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe\HxTsr.exe”. Any instances of hxtsr.exe not in this folder may be malware camouflaging itself as HxTsr.exe

item.title: Detection of PowerShell Execution via Sqlps.exe
item.description: This rule detects execution of a PowerShell code through the sqlps.exe utility, which is included in the standard set of utilities supplied with the MSSQL Server. Script blocks are not logged in this case, so this utility helps to bypass protection mechanisms based on the analysis of these logs.

item.title: Malicious PE Execution by Microsoft Visual Studio Debugger
item.description: There is an option for a MS VS Just-In-Time Debugger “vsjitdebugger.exe” to launch specified executable and attach a debugger. This option may be used adversaries to execute malicious code by signed verified binary. The debugger is installed alongside with Microsoft Visual Studio package.

item.title: Malware Shellcode in Verclsid Target Process
item.description: Detects a process access to verclsid.exe that injects shellcode from a Microsoft Office application / VBA macro

item.description: This rule detects a suspicious crash of the Microsoft Malware Protection Engine

item.title: Modifies the Registry From a ADS
item.description: Detects the import of an alternate data stream with regini.exe, regini.exe can be used to modify registry keys.

item.title: Modifies the Registry From a File
item.description: Detects the execution of regini.exe which can be used to modify registry keys, the changes are imported from one or more text files.

item.title: Monitoring For Persistence Via BITS
item.description: BITS will allow you to schedule a command to execute after a successful download to notify you that the job is finished. When the job runs on the system the command specified in the BITS job will be executed. This can be abused by actors to create a backdoor within the system and for persistence. It will be chained in a BITS job to schedule the download of malware/additional binaries and execute the program after being downloaded

item.title: Monitoring Winget For LOLbin Execution
item.description: Adversaries can abuse winget to download payloads remotely and execute them without touching disk. Winget will be included by default in Windows 10 and is already available in Windows 10 insider programs. The manifest option enables you to install an application by passing in a YAML file directly to the client. Winget can be used to download and install exe’s, msi, msix files later.

item.title: Monitoring Wuauclt.exe For Lolbas Execution Of DLL
item.description: Adversaries can abuse wuauclt.exe (Windows Update client) to run code execution by specifying an arbitrary DLL.

item.title: Mounted Share Deleted
item.description: Detects when when a mounted share is removed. Adversaries may remove share connections that are no longer useful in order to clean up traces of their operation

item.title: Office Security Settings Changed
item.description: Detects registry changes to Office macro settings. The TrustRecords contain information on executed macro-enabled documents. (see references)

item.title: PortProxy Registry Key
item.description: Detects the modification of PortProxy registry key which is used for port forwarding. For command execution see rule win_netsh_port_fwd.yml.

item.title: Possible Process Hollowing Image Loading
item.description: Detects Loading of samlib.dll, WinSCard.dll from untypical process e.g. through process hollowing by Mimikatz

item.title: Possible Ransomware or Unauthorized MBR Modifications
item.description: Detects, possibly, malicious unauthorized usage of bcdedit.exe

item.title: PowerShell Called from an Executable Version Mismatch
item.description: Detects PowerShell called from an executable by the version mismatch method

item.title: Powershell Defender Base64 MpPreference
item.description: Detects base64 encoded PowerShell code that modifies Windows Defender

item.title: Powershell Defender Disable Scan Feature
item.description: Detects requests to disable Microsoft Defender features using PowerShell commands

item.title: Powershell Defender Exclusion
item.description: Detects requests to exclude files, folders or processes from Antivirus scanning using PowerShell cmdlets

item.title: PowerShell Deleted Mounted Share
item.description: Detects when when a mounted share is removed. Adversaries may remove share connections that are no longer useful in order to clean up traces of their operation

item.title: Powershell Detect Virtualization Environment
item.description: Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox

item.title: PowerShell Encoded Character Syntax
item.description: Detects suspicious encoded character syntax often used for defense evasion

item.title: Powershell Store File In Alternate Data Stream
item.description: Storing files in Alternate Data Stream (ADS) similar to Astaroth malware.

item.title: Powershell Timestomp
item.description: Adversaries may modify file time attributes to hide new or changes to existing files. Timestomping is a technique that modifies the timestamps of a file (the modify, access, create, and change times), often to mimic files that are in the same folder.

item.title: Powershell Used To Disable Windows Defender AV Security Monitoring
item.description: Detects attackers attempting to disable Windows Defender using Powershell

item.title: Process Dump via Comsvcs DLL
item.description: Detects process memory dump via comsvcs.dll and rundll32

item.title: Proxy Execution Via Explorer.exe
item.description: Attackers can use explorer.exe for evading defense mechanisms

item.title: Raccine Uninstall
item.description: Detects commands that indicate a Raccine removal from an end system. Raccine is a free ransomware protection tool.

item.title: Raw Disk Access Using Illegitimate Tools
item.description: Raw disk access using illegitimate tools, possible defence evasion

item.title: Raw Paste Service Access
item.description: Detects direct access to raw pastes in different paste services often used by malware in their second stages to download malicious code in encrypted or encoded form

item.title: RDP Sensitive Settings Changed
item.description: Detects changes to RDP terminal service sensitive settings

item.title: RdrLeakDiag Process Dump
item.description: Detects uses of the rdrleakdiag.exe LOLOBIN utility to dump process memory

item.title: RedMimicry Winnti Playbook Dropped File
item.description: Detects actions caused by the RedMimicry Winnti playbook

item.title: RedMimicry Winnti Playbook Execute
item.description: Detects actions caused by the RedMimicry Winnti playbook

item.title: RedMimicry Winnti Playbook Registry Manipulation
item.description: Detects actions caused by the RedMimicry Winnti playbook

item.title: Remote Code Execute via Winrm.vbs
item.description: Detects an attempt to execute code or create service on remote host via winrm.vbs.

item.title: Remote Registry Management Using Reg Utility
item.description: Remote registry management using REG utility from non-admin workstation

item.title: Removal Amsi Provider Reg Key
item.description: Remove the AMSI Provider registry key in HKLM\Software\Microsoft\AMSI to disable AMSI inspection

item.title: Removal of Potential COM Hijacking Registry Keys
item.description: A General detection to trigger for processes removing .*\shell\open\command registry keys. Registry keys that might have been used for COM hijacking activities.

item.title: Remove Windows Defender Definition Files
item.description: Adversaries may disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their tools and activities by removing Windows Defender Definition Files

item.title: Renamed jusched.exe
item.description: Detects renamed jusched.exe used by cobalt group

item.title: Renamed MegaSync
item.description: Detects the execution of a renamed meg.exe of MegaSync during incident response engagements associated with ransomware families like Nefilim, Sodinokibi, Pysa, and Conti.

item.title: Renamed PAExec
item.description: Detects suspicious renamed PAExec execution as often used by attackers

item.title: Root Certificate Installed
item.description: Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.

item.title: Run Once Task Configuration in Registry
item.description: Rule to detect the configuration of Run Once registry key. Configured payload can be run by runonce.exe /AlternateShellStartup

item.title: Run Once Task Execution as Configured in Registry
item.description: This rule detects the execution of Run Once task as configured in the registry

item.title: Run PowerShell Script from ADS
item.description: Detects PowerShell script execution from Alternate Data Stream (ADS)

item.title: Run PowerShell Script from Redirected Input Stream
item.description: Detects PowerShell script execution via input stream redirect

item.title: Set Windows System File with Attrib
item.description: Marks a file as a system file using the attrib.exe utility

item.title: Shadow Copies Deletion Using Operating Systems Utilities
item.description: Shadow Copies deletion using operating systems utilities

item.title: ShimCache Flush
item.description: Detects actions that clear the local ShimCache and remove forensic evidence

item.title: SQL Client Tools PowerShell Session Detection
item.description: This rule detects execution of a PowerShell code through the sqltoolsps.exe utility, which is included in the standard set of utilities supplied with the Microsoft SQL Server Management studio. Script blocks are not logged in this case, so this utility helps to bypass protection mechanisms based on the analysis of these logs.

item.title: Squirrel Lolbin
item.description: Detects Possible Squirrel Packages Manager as Lolbin

item.title: Steganography Hide Zip Information in Picture File
item.description: Detects appending of zip file to image

item.title: Steganography Unzip Hidden Information From Picture File
item.description: Detects extracting of zip file from image file

item.title: Stop Or Remove Antivirus Service
item.description: Adversaries may disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their tools and activities by stopping antivirus service

item.title: Suspcious CLR Logs Creation
item.description: Detects suspicious .NET assembly executions. Could detect using Cobalt Strike’s command execute-assembly.

item.title: Suspect Svchost Memory Asccess
item.description: Detects suspect access to svchost process memory such as that used by Invoke-Phantom to kill the winRM windows event logging service.

item.title: Suspicious Atbroker Execution
item.description: Atbroker executing non-deafualt Assistive Technology applications

item.title: Suspicious Auditpol Usage
item.description: Threat actors can use auditpol binary to change audit policy configuration to impair detection capability. This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.

item.title: Suspicious Calculator Usage
item.description: Detects suspicious use of calc.exe with command line parameters or in a suspicious directory, which is likely caused by some PoC or detection evasion

item.title: Suspicious Copy From or To System32
item.description: Detects a suspicious copy command that copies a system program from System32 to another directory on disk - sometimes used to use LOLBINs like certutil or desktopimgdownldr to a different location with a different name

item.title: Suspicious Desktopimgdownldr Target File
item.description: Detects a suspicious Microsoft desktopimgdownldr file creation that stores a file to a suspicious location or contains a file with a suspicious extension

item.title: Suspicious Download File Extension with Bits
item.description: Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute or clean up after malicious payloads. Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is a low-bandwidth, asynchronous file transfer mechanism exposed through Component Object Model

item.title: Suspicious Driver Loaded By User
item.description: Detects the loading of drivers via ‘SeLoadDriverPrivilege’ required to load or unload a device driver. With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode. This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers. If you exclude privileged users/admins and processes, which are allowed to do so, you are maybe left with bad programs trying to load malicious kernel drivers. This will detect Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs) and the usage of Sysinternals and various other tools. So you have to work with a whitelist to find the bad stuff.

item.title: Suspicious Esentutl Use
item.description: Detects flags often used with the LOLBAS Esentutl for malicious activity. It could be used in rare cases by administrators to access locked files or during maintenance.

item.title: Suspicious Eventlog Clear or Configuration Using Wevtutil
item.description: Detects clearing or configuration of eventlogs using wevtutil, powershell and wmic. Might be used by ransomwares during the attack (seen by NotPetya and others).

item.title: Suspicious ftp.exe
item.description: Detects renamed ftp.exe, ftp.exe script execution and child processes ran by ftp.exe

item.title: Suspicious GUP Usage
item.description: Detects execution of the Notepad++ updater in a suspicious directory, which is often used in DLL side-loading attacks

item.title: Suspicious Invoke-Item From Mount-DiskImage
item.description: Adversaries may abuse container files such as disk image (.iso, .vhd) file formats to deliver malicious payloads that may not be tagged with MOTW.

item.title: Suspicious IO.FileStream
item.description: Open a handle on the drive volume via the \.\ DOS device path specifier and perform direct access read of the first few bytes of the volume.

item.title: Suspicious Load of Advapi31.dll
item.description: Detects the load of advapi31.dll by a process running in an uncommon folder

item.title: Suspicious Mount-DiskImage
item.description: Adversaries may abuse container files such as disk image (.iso, .vhd) file formats to deliver malicious payloads that may not be tagged with MOTW.

item.title: Suspicious Ntdll Pipe Redirection
item.description: Detects command that type the content of ntdll.dll to a different file or a pipe in order to evade AV / EDR detection

item.title: Suspicious OfflineScannerShell.exe Execution From Another Folder
item.description: Use OfflineScannerShell.exe to execute mpclient.dll library in the current working directory

item.title: Suspicious Parent of Csc.exe
item.description: Detects a suspicious parent of csc.exe, which could by a sign of payload delivery

item.title: Suspicious PowerShell Cmdline
item.description: Detects the PowerShell command lines with reversed strings

item.title: Suspicious PowerShell Command Line
item.description: Detects the PowerShell command lines with special characters

item.title: Suspicious PROCEXP152.sys File Created In TMP
item.description: Detects the creation of the PROCEXP152.sys file in the application-data local temporary folder. This driver is used by Sysinternals Process Explorer but also by KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU) or Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU.

item.title: Suspicious Registration via cscript.exe
item.description: Detects when the registration of a VSS/VDS Provider as a COM+ application.

item.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Activity Invoking Sys File
item.description: Detects suspicious process related to rundll32 based on command line that includes a *.sys file as seen being used by UNC2452

item.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Invoking Inline VBScript
item.description: Detects suspicious process related to rundll32 based on command line that invokes inline VBScript as seen being used by UNC2452

item.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Script in CommandLine
item.description: Detects suspicious process related to rundll32 based on arguments

item.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Setupapi.dll Activity
item.description: setupapi.dll library provide InstallHinfSection function for processing INF files. INF file may contain instructions allowing to create values in the registry, modify files and install drivers. This technique could be used to obtain persistence via modifying one of Run or RunOnce registry keys, run process or use other DLLs chain calls (see references) InstallHinfSection function in setupapi.dll calls runonce.exe executable regardless of actual content of INF file.

item.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Without Any CommandLine Params
item.description: Detects suspicious start of rundll32.exe without any parameters as found in CobaltStrike beacon activity

item.title: Suspicious Runscripthelper.exe
item.description: Detects execution of powershell scripts via Runscripthelper.exe

item.title: Suspicious Service Binary Directory
item.description: Detects a service binary running in a suspicious directory

item.title: Suspicious Service Installed
item.description: Detects installation of NalDrv or PROCEXP152 services via registry-keys to non-system32 folders. Both services are used in the tool Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU)

item.title: Suspicious Task Added by Bitsadmin
item.description: Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute or clean up after malicious payloads. Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is a low-bandwidth, asynchronous file transfer mechanism exposed through Component Object Model

item.title: Suspicious Task Added by Powershell
item.description: Adversaries may abuse BITS jobs to persistently execute or clean up after malicious payloads. Windows Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is a low-bandwidth, asynchronous file transfer mechanism exposed through Component Object Model

item.title: Suspicious Usage of the Manage-bde.wsf Script
item.description: Detects a usage of the manage-bde.wsf script that may indicate an attempt of proxy execution from script

item.title: Suspicious VBoxDrvInst.exe Parameters
item.description: Detect VBoxDrvInst.exe run with parameters allowing processing INF file. This allows to create values in the registry and install drivers. For example one could use this technique to obtain persistence via modifying one of Run or RunOnce registry keys

item.title: Suspicious ZipExec Execution
item.description: ZipExec is a Proof-of-Concept (POC) tool to wrap binary-based tools into a password-protected zip file.

item.title: SyncAppvPublishingServer Execution to Bypass Powershell Restriction
item.description: Detects SyncAppvPublishingServer process execution which usually utilized by adversaries to bypass PowerShell execution restrictions.

item.title: Sysinternals SDelete File Deletion
item.description: A General detection to trigger for the deletion of files by Sysinternals SDelete. It looks for the common name pattern used to rename files.

item.title: Sysinternals SDelete Registry Keys
item.description: A General detection to trigger for the creation or modification of .*\Software\Sysinternals\SDelete registry keys. Indicators of the use of Sysinternals SDelete tool.

item.title: Sysmon Channel Reference Deletion
item.description: Potential threat actor tampering with Sysmon manifest and eventually disabling it

item.title: Sysmon Configuration Error
item.description: Someone try to hide from Sysmon

item.title: Sysmon Configuration Modification
item.description: Someone try to hide from Sysmon

item.title: Tamper Windows Defender
item.description: Attempting to disable scheduled scanning and other parts of windows defender atp.

item.title: Telegram API Access
item.description: Detects suspicious requests to Telegram API without the usual Telegram User-Agent

item.title: Time Travel Debugging Utility Usage
item.description: Detects usage of Time Travel Debugging Utility. Adversaries can execute malicious processes and dump processes, such as lsass.exe, via tttracer.exe.

item.title: Turla ComRAT
item.description: Detects Turla ComRAT patterns

item.title: UAC Bypass Via Wsreset
item.description: Unfixed method for UAC bypass from windows 10. WSReset.exe file associated with the Windows Store. It will run a binary file contained in a low-privilege registry.

item.title: UAC Bypass With Fake DLL
item.description: Attempts to load dismcore.dll after dropping it

item.title: Unauthorized System Time Modification
item.description: Detect scenarios where a potentially unauthorized application or user is modifying the system time.

item.title: Uninstall Crowdstrike Falcon
item.description: Adversaries may disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their tools and activities by uninstalling Crowdstrike Falcon

item.title: Using AppVLP To Circumvent ASR File Path Rule
item.description: Application Virtualization Utility is included with Microsoft Office. We are able to abuse “AppVLP” to execute shell commands. Normally, this binary is used for Application Virtualization, but we can use it as an abuse binary to circumvent the ASR file path rule folder or to mark a file as a system file.

item.title: Using SettingSyncHost.exe as LOLBin
item.description: Detects using SettingSyncHost.exe to run hijacked binary

item.title: Verclsid.exe Runs COM Object
item.description: Detects when verclsid.exe is used to run COM object via GUID

item.title: Visual Basic Command Line Compiler Usage
item.description: Detects successful code compilation via Visual Basic Command Line Compiler that utilizes Windows Resource to Object Converter.

item.title: Wdigest CredGuard Registry Modification
item.description: Detects potential malicious modification of the property value of IsCredGuardEnabled from HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest to disable Cred Guard on a system. This is usually used with UseLogonCredential to manipulate the caching credentials.

item.title: Wdigest Enable UseLogonCredential
item.description: Detects potential malicious modification of the property value of UseLogonCredential from HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest to enable clear-text credentials

item.title: Weak Encryption Enabled and Kerberoast
item.description: Detects scenario where weak encryption is enabled for a user profile which could be used for hash/password cracking.

item.title: Windows Spooler Service Suspicious Binary Load
item.description: Detect DLL Load from Spooler Service backup folder

item.title: Windows Spooler Service Suspicious File Deletion
item.description: Detect DLL deletions from Spooler Service driver folder

item.title: Winnti Malware HK University Campaign
item.description: Detects specific process characteristics of Winnti malware noticed in Dec/Jan 2020 in a campaign against Honk Kong universities

item.title: Winword.exe Loads Suspicious DLL
item.description: Detects Winword.exe loading of custmom dll via /l cmd switch

item.title: WMIC Loading Scripting Libraries
item.description: Detects threat actors proxy executing code and bypassing application controls by leveraging wmic and the /FORMAT argument switch to download and execute an XSL file (i.e js, vbs, etc).

item.title: Wmic Uninstall Security Product
item.description: Detects deinstallation of security products using WMIC utility

item.title: Write Protect For Storage Disabled
item.description: Looks for changes to registry to disable any write-protect property for storage devices. This could be a precursor to a ransomware attack and has been an observed technique used by cypherpunk group.

item.title: Writing Of Malicious Files To The Fonts Folder
item.description: Monitors for the hiding possible malicious files in the C:\Windows\Fonts\ location. This folder doesn’t require admin privillege to be written and executed from.

item.title: WSL Execution
item.description: Detects Possible usage of Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) binary as a LOLBIN

item.title: Wuauclt Network Connection
item.description: Detects the use of the Windows Update Client binary (wuauclt.exe) to proxy execute code and making a network connections. One could easily make the DLL spawn a new process and inject to it to proxy the network connection and bypass this rule.
